newsitem.title: USA: U.S. official testifies on donor's ties to Clinton.
newsitem.headline: U.S. official testifies on donor's ties to Clinton.

text.p: Nancy Soderberg, a top national security aide to President Bill Clinton, testified before a federal grand jury about White House contacts with Democratic donor Roger Tamraz, the Washington Post reported on Thursday.
The grand jury is investigating whether anyone tried to bribe or pressure administration officials into supporting Tamraz or his proposal to build a multibillion-dollar pipeline from the Caspian Sea.
Soderberg is in line to be nominated as U.S. representative to the United Nations for special political affairs.
The U.N. job carries with it ambassadorial rank and requires Senate confirmation, so how she handled the Tamraz affair could directly affect her future, the Post said.

Soderberg backed her deputy Sheila Heslin, in 1995 and 1996 when both Donald Fowler, co-chairman of the Democratic Party and a high-ranking Energy Department official, allegedly tried to pressure Heslin to support Tamarz in his efforts to seek U.S. endorsement of his pipeline proposal.
Soderberg also agreed with Heslin that Tamraz should not be allowed into the White House because of suspicions he was misrepresenting the U.S. position on his pipeline.
Soderberg conveyed the NSC view to Fowler, but not other top Clinton aides, and the DNC continued to invite Tamraz to events with Clinton, the newspaper said.
At one of those events Tamraz spoke with the president about his project, and Clinton directed his chief of staff Mack McLarty to follow up.

Heslin told the grand jury recently that a top Energy Department official, Jack Carter, told her Tamraz was a big Democratic donor and a White House meeting to discuss his project would result in further contributions to the president's 1996 campaign.
But Heslin said she would not drop her opposition to the project or Tamraz's White House access.
